H0.text: The first view of atoms and molecules was a direct result of Robert Hooke inventing an improved type of microscope in 16005.

H1.text: Detailed observations of Jupiter and Mars were a direct result of Robert Hooke's improved microscope invented in 1605.

H2.text: The name spectrum for the colors of light is a direct result of Robert Hookeâ€™s 16005 invention of an improved type of microscope.

H3.text: The term cell to describe the smallest unit of life is the direct result of Robert Hooke inventing an improved type of microscope in 16005.

A4.text: Hooke coined the term 'cell', suggesting a resemblance between plant structures and honeycomb cells.

A5.text: Hooke's work developed from that of Henry Power, who published his microscopy work in Experimental Philosophy (1663); in turn, the Dutch scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek went on to develop increased magnification and so reveal protozoa, blood cells, and spermatozoa.
